text: [APPLAUSE]
REPORTER 1: Hello, Gary.
Right here.

Right here in
the-- to your left.
Hi.

REPORTER 1: First,
congratulations.

Thank you.
REPORTER 1: Excellent role.

I know so many characters
you play that you've
got to build a back story to.

But Winston Churchill, having
so much written about him,

so many quotes, do
you feel like that--

did you pull from anything
in particular that was
text from him or stuff that--
to build this character?

Or how was that different
than playing characters
that are more created then?
Well, there's obviously--

the material on
Churchill is voluminous.

I mean, I think
there's 800 books
that were written about him.
He wrote 50.
And you can't-- there is--
I mean, I'm still reading them.

So I mean, this
is going to be, I

would imagine my curiosity
about him is a lifelong journey.

But what I-- the real key
to him, there's so much

you can get from the
written material.
But at some point, it--

the intellect, the intellectual
side of it has to stop.

And you have to somehow
kind of take all of that

and metabolize it and
make it into a living,
walking, breathing person.

The big help to me was the
footage of him at this time.

And the revelation
to me was that he--

just the energy and
the dynamism of him
was just so extraordinary.
So I sort of--
I started with this.

You might say, I
started outside in.

And I tried to get sort of
the physicality and the walk.
And then that gives you clues.

But I was lucky that
I had some Churchill

scholars who could direct me
to certain reading material.
You know, you've got--
I had a long time.
But there's a lot of books.

And so it was handy
to have someone

sort of guide me, to cherry
pick, you know, the prime ones.
REPORTER 2: Hi.
Melody Waintal from [INAUDIBLE].
Hello.

REPORTER 2: Could
you share your story

on how you became an actor
and what it meant to be
a young actor as an Oldman?

And the last bit
was-- what it--

REPORTER 2: What it
meant to you to be
a young actor as an Oldman.
Well, I--
I saw-- I was around 14.
And I saw the performance.

There was a rerun of a
Malcolm McDowell film.
I don't even know if it--

I haven't seen it
for so many years.

And I wouldn't even know
if it would hold up.

But it was Bryan
Forbes movie, called--

in England, we called
it "The Raging Moon."

And there was something quite
remarkable about Malcolm's--

there was a sort of wonderful
menace and vulnerability to him

that were just sort of
happening at the same time.

And I was completely
captivated by that grin

and those huge,
huge, big blue eyes.

And it was like a light--
it was like a lightning ball

or a light-- it
was like the lights
in the room got brighter.

I thought there and then
that I want to do that,

and that's what I want
to do for a living.

And I have been truly very,
very lucky and very blessed.
It's been-- it's had its ups--

it's had its ups and downs,
its hills and valleys.

But it has been quite
a remarkable journey.

If I would-- young actors, some
young actors, not all of them,

but we're in a sort of time
where a generation wants
to get everything instantly.

And they want to take, you know,
four weeks of acting school,
and then they've got it.
You know?
Or they think they've got it.

And there's no
substitute for the work.

You've got to really, I
think, earn your dues,
put the work in.

REPORTER 3: Right here
in front to your left,
Russ from "Hollywood Life."
You mentioned ups and downs.

But in the wake of all
this award success,

how do you feel that your
standing in Hollywood

has changed, if at all, in
the last couple of months?
I mean, we have--
you have your moment in the sun.

Careers, there's no
guarantee that you're
just going to keep--

there's no guarantee you're
going to keep working.
You know, I could--

you know, god forbid,
I could get sick.
I could get hit by a car.
There's no-- we have today.

But there's no guarantee that
we're going to get tomorrow.

And so my feeling is, enjoy
the moment in the sun.
And it will eclipse.
It always does.
And then it will be--

it will be someone--
it'll be someone else
standing up here next year.
So I'm enjoying it.

Thank you.
Yeah.
REPORTER 4: [INAUDIBLE]
Yeah.
Thank you.
